title: China Eximbank provides RMB 67.26 million government concessional loan for Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40532)
description: On July 23, 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Cook Islands signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project. Then, in August 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of the Cook Islands signed an RMB 74.1 million ($9.6 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a 1.8% interest rate, a 5-year grace period, and a 20-year maturity rate. The loan’s final maturity date is August 2028. The loan’s outstanding amount was RMB 9,224,000 as of September 2019 and RMB 8,298,000 as of December 2019. RMB 67.26 million ($8.65 million) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project (as captured via Project ID#37877) and RMB 6.84 million ($950,000) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project (as captured via Project ID#40532).  The purpose of the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project was to construct a sports arena in Tereora in advance of the 2009 South Pacific Mini Games.   China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on or around October 1, 2008. 60 Chinese workers were employed during the construction phase. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on July 31, 2009. The construction of the sports arena, which was later renamed to the Bluesky Sports Arena, was completed in time for the Cook Islands to host the 2009 South Pacific Mini Games.  However, this project was also a subject of local debate and controversy. In February 2008, the Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce demanded that the Government of the Cook Islands abandon its plans to contract a China Eximbank loan for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project, and threatened legal action against the central government. It announced that it was prepared to apply to the Rarotonga High Court for a declaratory judgment on whether the central government had acted illegally in proceeding with the China Eximbank loan and plans for the sports complex arena. A draft statement of claim was prepared for the court naming five government officials as defendants. The Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce then sent the draft statement of claim to the Prime Minister’s office, the audit office, the public expenditure review committee, and Crown Law.  The Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce argued that the central government had breached the MFEM (Ministry of Finance) Act, which requires that all government officials must prudently manage the fiscal risks facing the crown. A number of matters breaching the MFEM Act were identified, including that the central government would increase the country's debt with a foreign currency loan for an open-ended design and build project with a foreign contractor. The Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce asked the central government to consult with sports codes in order to commit to a cost effective upgrade of village sports facilities; identify options for modifying existing facilities to host the world youth netball champs and mini games; and consider the possibility of some new special purpose facilities.  2009 Pacific Mini Games Chief Executive David Lobb was also highly critical of the plans for the sports arena, saying the design did not meet the minimum games requirements and would not provide a lasting legacy for the sportspeople of the Cook Islands. CISNOC (Cook Islands Sports and National Olympic Committee) President Tiki Matapo echoed Lobb's concerns and agreed that the country's sporting bodies had not been properly consulted on the design of the complex. In a written statement, the the Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce said its concerns were underpinned by the two examples of poor design and workmanship in the Chinese Government-financed courthouse and police station: ‘The chamber has previously expressed concern on a number of aspects of the MSF (complex) project including the foreign exchange risk, the lack of a transparent and accountable process (one that would enable the true finance rate to be determined) and that local contractors are being denied the opportunity to construct any such facility with the subsequent benefits this would have for the Cook Islands economy.’  Then, in late April 2008, the Chinese Government expressed concern about the negative public comments and indicated that the China Eximbank loan offer might be withdrawn.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Indoor Sports Stadium & Upgrade of Existing Sports Facilities Project, the Multi-Functional Indoor Sports Stadium Project, and The Bluesky Sports Arena Project. The Chinese project title is 库克体育馆项目 or 多功能室内体育馆. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020. 3. The Chinese Government provided grant funding in 2016 and 2017 to renovate Telecom (Bluesky) Sports Arena, the courthouse, and the police station (as captured via Project ID#64016 and #64018).
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 67.26 million government concessional loan for Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40532)

# Description
On July 23, 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Cook Islands signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project. Then, in August 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of the Cook Islands signed an RMB 74.1 million ($9.6 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a 1.8% interest rate, a 5-year grace period, and a 20-year maturity rate. The loan’s final maturity date is August 2028. The loan’s outstanding amount was RMB 9,224,000 as of September 2019 and RMB 8,298,000 as of December 2019. RMB 67.26 million ($8.65 million) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project (as captured via Project ID#37877) and RMB 6.84 million ($950,000) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project (as captured via Project ID#40532).  The purpose of the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project was to construct a sports arena in Tereora in advance of the 2009 South Pacific Mini Games.   China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on or around October 1, 2008. 60 Chinese workers were employed during the construction phase. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on July 31, 2009. The construction of the sports arena, which was later renamed to the Bluesky Sports Arena, was completed in time for the Cook Islands to host the 2009 South Pacific Mini Games.  However, this project was also a subject of local debate and controversy. In February 2008, the Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce demanded that the Government of the Cook Islands abandon its plans to contract a China Eximbank loan for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project, and threatened legal action against the central government. It announced that it was prepared to apply to the Rarotonga High Court for a declaratory judgment on whether the central government had acted illegally in proceeding with the China Eximbank loan and plans for the sports complex arena. A draft statement of claim was prepared for the court naming five government officials as defendants. The Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce then sent the draft statement of claim to the Prime Minister’s office, the audit office, the public expenditure review committee, and Crown Law.  The Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce argued that the central government had breached the MFEM (Ministry of Finance) Act, which requires that all government officials must prudently manage the fiscal risks facing the crown. A number of matters breaching the MFEM Act were identified, including that the central government would increase the country's debt with a foreign currency loan for an open-ended design and build project with a foreign contractor. The Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce asked the central government to consult with sports codes in order to commit to a cost effective upgrade of village sports facilities; identify options for modifying existing facilities to host the world youth netball champs and mini games; and consider the possibility of some new special purpose facilities.  2009 Pacific Mini Games Chief Executive David Lobb was also highly critical of the plans for the sports arena, saying the design did not meet the minimum games requirements and would not provide a lasting legacy for the sportspeople of the Cook Islands. CISNOC (Cook Islands Sports and National Olympic Committee) President Tiki Matapo echoed Lobb's concerns and agreed that the country's sporting bodies had not been properly consulted on the design of the complex. In a written statement, the the Cook Islands Chamber of Commerce said its concerns were underpinned by the two examples of poor design and workmanship in the Chinese Government-financed courthouse and police station: ‘The chamber has previously expressed concern on a number of aspects of the MSF (complex) project including the foreign exchange risk, the lack of a transparent and accountable process (one that would enable the true finance rate to be determined) and that local contractors are being denied the opportunity to construct any such facility with the subsequent benefits this would have for the Cook Islands economy.’  Then, in late April 2008, the Chinese Government expressed concern about the negative public comments and indicated that the China Eximbank loan offer might be withdrawn.
justification: Project is focused on sports arena construction, which is a social development project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of sports arena for South Pacific Mini Games, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 6.84 million government concessional loan for Ministry of Education Administrative Building (Linked to Project ID#37877)
description: On July 23, 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Cook Islands signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project. Then, in August 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of the Cook Islands signed an RMB 74.1 million (US $9.6 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project.   The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: 1.8% interest rate, 5-year grace period, and 20-year maturity rate. The loan’s final maturity date is August 2028.  RMB 67.26 million (US $8.65 million) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project (as captured via Project ID#37877) and RMB 6.84 million (US $ 950,000) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project (as captured via Project ID#40532).   The purpose of the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project was to construct a two-story, 800 square meter administrative building — with offices, conference rooms, and training facilities — for the Ministry of Education in Nikao. A local company, Mike Rennie Builders Ltd, was selected to implement the project. Construction began in December 2010 and the roof was installed in April 2011. The project was completed in January 2012.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 教育部综合楼项目. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 6.84 million government concessional loan for Ministry of Education Administrative Building (Linked to Project ID#37877)

# Description
On July 23, 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Cook Islands signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project. Then, in August 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of the Cook Islands signed an RMB 74.1 million (US $9.6 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project and the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project.   The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: 1.8% interest rate, 5-year grace period, and 20-year maturity rate. The loan’s final maturity date is August 2028.  RMB 67.26 million (US $8.65 million) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Telecom Sports Arena Construction Project (as captured via Project ID#37877) and RMB 6.84 million (US $ 950,000) of the GCL proceeds were allocated to the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project (as captured via Project ID#40532).   The purpose of the Ministry of Education Administrative Building Project was to construct a two-story, 800 square meter administrative building — with offices, conference rooms, and training facilities — for the Ministry of Education in Nikao. A local company, Mike Rennie Builders Ltd, was selected to implement the project. Construction began in December 2010 and the roof was installed in April 2011. The project was completed in January 2012.
justification: Project is focused on construction of an administrative building for education purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of two-story administrative building for Ministry of Education, includes offices, conference rooms, and training facilities

title: China Offered a 1.5 Million USD Grant to Build a Chinatown in San Jose, Costa Rica
description: In June 2008, the project of building a Chinatown in San Jose, Costa Rica was announced at an official ceremony that included Costa Rican president, Oscar Arias, Municipalidad de San José mayor, Johnny Araya and the mayor of Beijing, Guo Jinlong. The project was funded by the Costa Rican government, the city of San José, and a US$1.5 million grant from the People's Republic of China. The Chinatown officially opened on 5 December 2012, with a 550-meter pedestrian boulevard and a Tang Dynasty-style archway.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China Offered a 1.5 Million USD Grant to Build a Chinatown in San Jose, Costa Rica

# Description
In June 2008, the project of building a Chinatown in San Jose, Costa Rica was announced at an official ceremony that included Costa Rican president, Oscar Arias, Municipalidad de San José mayor, Johnny Araya and the mayor of Beijing, Guo Jinlong. The project was funded by the Costa Rican government, the city of San José, and a US$1.5 million grant from the People's Republic of China. The Chinatown officially opened on 5 December 2012, with a 550-meter pedestrian boulevard and a Tang Dynasty-style archway.
justification: Project focuses on cultural infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of Chinatown with pedestrian boulevard and cultural archway, funded as a social development project

title: Hanban completes Confucius Institute at the University of Costa Rica
description: On November 17, 2008, the University of Costa Rica and the Confucius Institute Headquarters signed a cooperation agreement for the establishment for the establishment of the Confucius Institute at the University of Costa Rica. The agreement had a validity period of five years. The Institute will facilitate Chinese language instruction and promote Chinese-Costa Rican relations. To establish the Institute, the University of Costa Rica intended to open a designated account in a local bank using USD $50,000 to $100,000 provided by China. Hanban also agreed to provide 3,000 volumes of books and multimedia materials and to send one or two Chinese instructors to teach at the Institute. The project will be jointly funded by Hanban and the University of Costa Rica.  The Institute opened in August 2009 and began hosting Chinese courses in March 2010.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban completes Confucius Institute at the University of Costa Rica

# Description
On November 17, 2008, the University of Costa Rica and the Confucius Institute Headquarters signed a cooperation agreement for the establishment for the establishment of the Confucius Institute at the University of Costa Rica. The agreement had a validity period of five years. The Institute will facilitate Chinese language instruction and promote Chinese-Costa Rican relations. To establish the Institute, the University of Costa Rica intended to open a designated account in a local bank using USD $50,000 to $100,000 provided by China. Hanban also agreed to provide 3,000 volumes of books and multimedia materials and to send one or two Chinese instructors to teach at the Institute. The project will be jointly funded by Hanban and the University of Costa Rica.  The Institute opened in August 2009 and began hosting Chinese courses in March 2010.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for Chinese language instruction and cultural promotion

title: CDB provides $40 million loan to National Bank of Costa Rica to support infrastructure and social development projects (Linked to Project ID#35549)
description: On November 17, 2008, China Development Bank (CDB) and the National Bank of Costa Rica -- a state-owned bank in Costa Rica -- signed a $40 million facility agreement. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to support infrastructure and social development projects in Costa Rica. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity of 5 years, a grace period of 0.5 years, an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR plus a 2.2% margin, a 2% default (penalty) interest rate, a commitment fee of 0.30%, and a one-time, upfront (management) fee of 0.60%. The borrower was responsible for making 9, equal semiannual repayments. Revenue from financial assets was collected in a collateral pledge account, out of which debt service was paid.
staff_comments: 1. The CDB facility (loan) agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/cemcy1xv0jstun9/2008%20CDB%20Loan%20Agreement%20with%20Costa%20Rica.pdf?dl=0. 2. Average 6-month LIBOR in November 2008 (2.658%) was used to calculate the all interest rate. The all-in interest rate was calculated as 4.858% (2.658% + 2.2%). 3. The CDB loan agreement specifies that '[a]t any time after the first repayment date, CDB shall have the right to request the borrower in writing, and the Borrower shall have the obligation […] to (i) enter into the Pledge Agreement with CDB and the Collateral Service Agent [which is Clearstream Banking in Luxemburg] and (ii) deposit into the Pledged Account Collateral [defined as any securities eligible for deposit in the Collateral Service Agent’s system] with an aggregate current value determined by [Clearstream Banking] to be no less than the amount of the Loans then outstanding.' Afterwards the borrower has to ensure that the pledged account always contains collateral with a value not less than the outstanding amount until the final maturity date. 4. This CDB loan is not captured in the China-Latin America Finance Database, which is co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
CDB provides $40 million loan to National Bank of Costa Rica to support infrastructure and social development projects (Linked to Project ID#35549)

# Description
On November 17, 2008, China Development Bank (CDB) and the National Bank of Costa Rica -- a state-owned bank in Costa Rica -- signed a $40 million facility agreement. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to support infrastructure and social development projects in Costa Rica. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity of 5 years, a grace period of 0.5 years, an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR plus a 2.2% margin, a 2% default (penalty) interest rate, a commitment fee of 0.30%, and a one-time, upfront (management) fee of 0.60%. The borrower was responsible for making 9, equal semiannual repayments. Revenue from financial assets was collected in a collateral pledge account, out of which debt service was paid.
justification: Loan facility for general infrastructure and social development without specific environmental or energy transition focus
evidence: General infrastructure and social development projects mentioned without specific details, financial services nature of the loan

title: Chinese Government provides $12 million grant for Container Inspection Equipment Project
description: In 2008, the Chinese Government donated two mobile scanners to the Government of Costa Rica. Each scanner was worth $6 million. The scanners were equipped with X-ray technology for examining the contents of vehicles and containers. The recipient of the donation was the Costa Rica Ministry of Environment and Energy (MINAE). According to a 2018 work report (INFORME DE LABORES), the scanners were used in tests but never for daily operation. In 2015, they were taken to the State Phytosanitary (Plant Health) Service for further evaluation. The State Phytosanitary Service discovered that the scanners were unable to distinguish between organic and inorganic materials, and the Government of Costa Rica decided not to renew the contract to maintain the equipment. Then, in July 2016, the Government of Costa Rica rejected a second offer from the Chinese Government of three additional container inspection equipment scanners (see Project ID#54880).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government provides $12 million grant for Container Inspection Equipment Project

# Description
In 2008, the Chinese Government donated two mobile scanners to the Government of Costa Rica. Each scanner was worth $6 million. The scanners were equipped with X-ray technology for examining the contents of vehicles and containers. The recipient of the donation was the Costa Rica Ministry of Environment and Energy (MINAE). According to a 2018 work report (INFORME DE LABORES), the scanners were used in tests but never for daily operation. In 2015, they were taken to the State Phytosanitary (Plant Health) Service for further evaluation. The State Phytosanitary Service discovered that the scanners were unable to distinguish between organic and inorganic materials, and the Government of Costa Rica decided not to renew the contract to maintain the equipment. Then, in July 2016, the Government of Costa Rica rejected a second offer from the Chinese Government of three additional container inspection equipment scanners (see Project ID#54880).
justification: Project involves container inspection equipment for trade regulation purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Mobile scanners with X-ray technology for examining vehicle and container contents, donated to Ministry of Environment and Energy but used for trade/security purposes

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 240 million government concessional loan for E-Government Project
description: On January 7, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an RMB 240 million (CFA 15 billion) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for an E-Government Project. The loan was then ratified by the Government of Cote d'Ivoire on September 18, 2008. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the RMB 240 million (CFA 15 billion) loan was fully disbursed in a single tranche on December 31, 2013.   This project involved the construction of a data center located in Grand-Bassam, as well as fiber optic cable connecting Abidjan and Yamoussoukro. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project encountered multiple delays and was not formally launched until October 3, 2011. Construction on the data center was was completed on November 9, 2012. The fiber-optic cable from Abidjan and Yamoussoukro was laid. The entire e-government project planned to reach completion and come into use in the first half of 2013. However, its precise completion date is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Grand Bassam E-Government Data Center Project. The French project title is Le Projet e-gouvernement or Projet électronique d’e-gouvernement or Projet de réseau électronique gouvernemental. The Chinese project title is 的科特迪瓦国家数据中心 or 科特迪瓦电子政务网 or 科特迪瓦电子政府项目.2. In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it identifies this loan as a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC). However, the loan is denominated in RMB and China Eximbank PBCs are denominated in USD, so AidData treats it as a government concessional loan (GCL). 3. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 11200713504. The AMP project code is QSFQSDQSD.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 240 million government concessional loan for E-Government Project

# Description
On January 7, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an RMB 240 million (CFA 15 billion) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for an E-Government Project. The loan was then ratified by the Government of Cote d'Ivoire on September 18, 2008. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the RMB 240 million (CFA 15 billion) loan was fully disbursed in a single tranche on December 31, 2013.   This project involved the construction of a data center located in Grand-Bassam, as well as fiber optic cable connecting Abidjan and Yamoussoukro. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project encountered multiple delays and was not formally launched until October 3, 2011. Construction on the data center was was completed on November 9, 2012. The fiber-optic cable from Abidjan and Yamoussoukro was laid. The entire e-government project planned to reach completion and come into use in the first half of 2013. However, its precise completion date is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on digital infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of data center and fiber optic cable, e-government focus

title: China signs exchange of notes for anti-malaria medicines worth 2 million RMB to Cote D'Ivoire
description: On 1 September 2008, China signed an exchange of notes for donating anti-malaria medicines to Cote d'Ivoire worth 2 million RMB (130 million CFA). These funds were sourced either from the grant (project #66188) or interest-free loan (project #70529) signed that day.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China signs exchange of notes for anti-malaria medicines worth 2 million RMB to Cote D'Ivoire

# Description
On 1 September 2008, China signed an exchange of notes for donating anti-malaria medicines to Cote d'Ivoire worth 2 million RMB (130 million CFA). These funds were sourced either from the grant (project #66188) or interest-free loan (project #70529) signed that day.
justification: Project involves donation of medicines for public health purposes without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Anti-malaria medicines donation, healthcare sector project

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 3 million grant for Malaria Research and Control Center Project (Linked to #66116)
description: On 1 September 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an exchange of notes in which the Chinese Government agreed to provide an RMB 3 million grant for the Malaria Research and Control Center Project. According to the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, from March 14th to April 26th, experts from the Chinese Aid Malaria Prevention and Treatment center arrived to work. It should be noted that training was provided in addition to the grant. This project involved the establishment of a Malaria Research and Control Center (Centre de Recherche et de Lutte contre le Paludisme or CRLP) at the National Institute of Public Health (Institut national de Santé Publique or INSP) in the Adjame district of Abidjan. The implementing contractor is unknown. On 7 April 2009, Ivorian and Chinese government officials attended the opening ceremony for the center.  The Malaria Research and Control Center was badly damaged during the 2011 post-election crisis. The Chinese Government subsequently provided another grant to support rehabilitation of the center (see Project #66116).
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 抗疟中心 or 科特迪瓦抗疟中心 or 的中国－科特迪瓦疟疾防治中心 or 中国-科特迪瓦疟疾防治中心.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 3 million grant for Malaria Research and Control Center Project (Linked to #66116)

# Description
On 1 September 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an exchange of notes in which the Chinese Government agreed to provide an RMB 3 million grant for the Malaria Research and Control Center Project. According to the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, from March 14th to April 26th, experts from the Chinese Aid Malaria Prevention and Treatment center arrived to work. It should be noted that training was provided in addition to the grant. This project involved the establishment of a Malaria Research and Control Center (Centre de Recherche et de Lutte contre le Paludisme or CRLP) at the National Institute of Public Health (Institut national de Santé Publique or INSP) in the Adjame district of Abidjan. The implementing contractor is unknown. On 7 April 2009, Ivorian and Chinese government officials attended the opening ceremony for the center.  The Malaria Research and Control Center was badly damaged during the 2011 post-election crisis. The Chinese Government subsequently provided another grant to support rehabilitation of the center (see Project #66116).
justification: Project focuses on healthcare research and disease control without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Malaria research and control center, healthcare focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China donates office equipment to Ministry of Foreign Affairs
description: On December 29, 2008, China donated 10 million African francs worth of office equipment to the Ivory Coast's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The donation ceremony was attended by Ivory Coast Foreign Minister Youssouf Bakayokon and Chinese Ambassador Wei Wenhua.
combined_text:

GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

China donates office equipment to Ministry of Foreign Affairs

# Description
On December 29, 2008, China donated 10 million African francs worth of office equipment to the Ivory Coast's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The donation ceremony was attended by Ivory Coast Foreign Minister Youssouf Bakayokon and Chinese Ambassador Wei Wenhua.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment to government ministry, with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
